intro: Ranunculus acidotus, commonly known as the alpine buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers with five petals and a central cluster of stamens. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sunlight. Its leaves are palmately lobed, and the plant is known for its delicate, herbaceous appearance. Ranunculus acidotus is often found in alpine meadows and is adapted to cold climates with short growing seasons.
